page.lettertext:
fol.205r
S
r
Yo
r
last l
re
s came yesterdaie to my hand
dated the
first of this moneth, w
ch
hir
Ma
tie
reading dilligentlie hir
self, greatlie commended yo
r
stowte and plaine dealinge w
th
Buzenval
, and thereof she made the
Frenche Ambassado
r
acquainted
whoe affirmed that he made noe menc
o
n to Buzenvall of yo
w
but onelie that hir Ma
tie
was so advertised of his backwardnes:
And bicawse I have noe leisure at this present to write anie
further to the Content
of this yo
r
l
re
, I doe remitt yowe
wholie to hir Ma
ties
l
re
sent at this time, and to the perusall
of a Copie of hir l
re
to the
States,
by both w
ch
yowe maie
largelie understand hir Ma
ties
purpose at this time, w
ch
I
hope, I neade not require yowe to further more, than the
Cawse it self doth necessarelie require: And further I referre
yowe to such informacons as
M
r
Burnham
shall geve yowe
nowe from
Flushinge,
whoe is sent thither, w
th
hir Ma
ties
l
re
s to
S
r
Robart Sidneie
,
S
r
Thomas Morgan
,
S
r
Francis
Veere
,
S
r
Edward Norris
, and yo
r
self: and w
th
the l
re
s also to
the States, w
ch
he will send yowe./
Hir Ma
tie
would have yowe to be ernest w
th
the States for
the suspenc
o
n of the Placart for the taringe of the Englishe
Cloathes, after yowe have received informac
o
n from them, what
reasons theie have to impugne that placart, w
ch
as yowe shall
perceive by the late part of hir Ma
ties
l
re
s is probablie towched
and I thinke to be verefied by all former Ancient usages, and by
spetiall wordes of the treatie of the Enterco
r
se: of all w
ch
the M
r
chant
I am sure will geve yowe due informac
o
n. And so being sorie to
ende w
th
that w
ch
is trewe that hir Ma
tie
readinge yo
r
request to
retorne hether, hathe willed mee to require yowe not to desire yt untill
the ende of this sommer, for that she [seeth] even nowe the harvest
of publicque affayres is begonne./
From westm
r
this viij
th
of Maye.
1592
Yo
r
verie Loving frend
William Burghley
I wish to hear of s
o
e good success of
Enchus
e
and am sorry, for
e
da
u
ger of
e honest burgess
t
hesardes
his lyff at
stenwyck
